thread.title: UK GAS-Prompt firms on tighter supply and higher demand
thread.title_full: UK GAS-Prompt firms on tighter supply and higher demand

title: UK GAS-Prompt firms on tighter supply and higher demand
text:
* Day-ahead gas price up 0.25 pence/therm 
* Norwegian imports drop, demand edges higher 
July 8 (Reuters) - British prompt gas prices rose on Wednesday on less supply from Norway and cooler weather while weaker crude oil prices weighed on some forward contracts. 
Gas for delivery on Thursday rose 0.25 pence/therm at 43.75 p/therm by 0848 GMT, with gas for immediate delivery trading at 43.80 p/therm, up 0.20 p/therm on the previous session. 
Britain's gas network was undersupplied by 4.2 million cubic metres (mcm) per day with demand estimated by National Grid (LSE: NG.L - news ) at 181.9 mcm/day. 
Throughput from Total (Swiss: FP.SW - news ) 's St Fergus terminal dropped to around 16 mcm compared with 22 mcm in the previous session, National Grid data showed. 
Deliveries via Norway's Langeled pipeline, Britain's main import source, also edged lower to around 16 mcm from 18 mcm on Tuesday. 
"We expect significant withdrawals from medium-range storage sites today (to help balance supply and demand)," analysts at Thomson Reuters Point Carbon said. 
An ongoing disruption in gas output on the UK Continental Shelf has seen zero supply entering the Easington Dimlington terminal. 
Further out on the curve, the benchmark winter 2015 gas contract was up 0.20 p/therm at 47.15 p/therm. 
Further forward seasonal contracts, however, appeared to have followed Brent crude oil prices lower. 
Gas for Summer 2016 delivery edged 0.05 pence lower at 42.60 p/therm, and Winter 2016 traded at 48.80 pence, down 0.20 p/therm day on day. 
Front-month Brent crude futures were 60 cents lower at $56.25 a barrel at 0657 GMT, trading down more than 6 percent this week at levels last seen in April. 
"Pressure from falling oil prices could still offer downward direction to seasonal contracts," Marcel Boonaert, head of trading and portfolio at Wingas UK. 
He added that cooler weather forecast for Britain on Wednesday had lifted local distribution zone demand, explaining the uptick in prompt prices. 
Dutch day-ahead gas at the TTF hub was down 0.08 euros at 20.77 euros per megawatt-hour. 
Europe's benchmark carbon price was 0.04 euros higher at 7.51 euros per tonne on ICE Futures Europe. (Reporting by Oleg Vukmanovic in Milan; editing by Jason Neely)
